{{Sex (biology) sidebar}} '''Sequential hermaphroditism''' (called '''dichogamy''' in [[botany]]) is a type of [[hermaphroditism]] that occurs in many [[fish]], [[gastropod]]s, and plants. Sequential hermaphroditism occurs when the individual changes sex at some point in its life.
In animals, the different types of change are male to female ('''protandry'''), female to male ('''protogyny'''),<ref name='Warner'/> female to hermaphrodite ('''protogynous hermaphroditism'''), and male to hermaphrodite ('''protandrous hermaphroditism'''). Those that change gonadal sex can have both female and male germ cells in the [[gonad]]s or can change from one complete gonadal type to the other during their last life stage.<ref name='carauth'>{{cite journal | title=Freshwater cichlid ''Crenicara punctulata'' is a protogynous sequential hermaphrodite | journal=Copeia | year=2000 | first=L. L. | last=Carruth | volume=2000 | pages=71–82 | doi=10.1643/0045-8511(2000)2000[0071:fccpia]2.0.co;2}}</ref>
In plants, individual flowers are called dichogamous if their function has the two sexes separated in time, although the plant as a whole may have functionally male and functionally female flowers open at any one moment. A flower is protogynous if its function is first female, then male, and protandrous if its function is male then female. It used to be thought that this reduced [[inbreeding]], but it may be a more general mechanism for reducing pollen-pistil interference.
==Zoology==
===Protandry=== [[File:Anemone purple anemonefish.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ocellaris clownfish]], ''Amphiprion ocellaris'', a protandrous animal species]]
Protandrous hermaphrodites are animals that are born male and at some point in their lifespan change sex to female. Protandrous animals include [[Amphiprioninae|clownfish]]. Clownfish have a very structured society. In the ''[[Amphiprioninae#Taxonomy|Amphiprion]] percula'' species, there are zero to four individuals excluded from breeding and a breeding pair living in a [[sea anemone]]. [[Dominance hierarchy|Dominance]] is based on size, the female being the largest and the male being the second largest. The rest of the group is made up of progressively smaller non-breeders, which have no functioning gonads.<ref name='Buston p'>{{cite journal | title=Territory inheritance in clownfish | journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]] | year=2004 | first=P. M | last=Buston | volume=271 | pages=s252-s254| id=| pmc=1810038 | pmid=15252999 | doi=10.1098/rsbl.2003.0156}}</ref> If the female dies, the male gains weight and becomes the female for that group. The largest non-breeding fish then sexually matures and becomes the male of the group.<ref name='Buston'>{{cite journal | title=Does the Presence of Non-Breeders Enhance the Fitness of Breeders ? An Experimental Analysis in the Clown Anemonefish ''Amphiprion percula'' | journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology | year=2004 | first=P. | last=Buston | volume=57 | pages=23–31| id=| doi=10.1007/s00265-004-0833-2}}</ref>
Other protandrous fishes can be found in the classes [[clupeiformes]], [[siluriformes]], [[stomiiformes]], and within the perciform families [[pomacentridae]] and [[sparidae]]. Since these groups are distantly related and have many intermediate relatives that are not protandrous, it strongly suggests that protandry evolved multiple times.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Avise|first1=J. C.|last2=Mank|first2=J. E.|title=Evolutionary Perspectives on Hermaphroditism in Fishes|journal=Sexual Development|date=2009|volume=3|issue=2–3|pages=152–163|doi=10.1159/000223079}}</ref> Other examples of protandrous animals include: * The [[ctenophore]] ''[[Coeloplana]] gonoctena''. In this organism the females are bigger than the males and are only found during the summer. In contrast males are found year-round. * The flatworms ''[[Hymanella]] retenuova'' and ''[[Paravortex]] cardii''. * ''[[Laevapex fuscus]]'', a [[gastropod]], is described as being functionally protandric. The [[sperm]] matures in late winter and early spring, the eggs mature in early summer, and [[copulation]] occurs only in June. This shows that males cannot reproduce until the females appear, thus why they are considered to be functionally protandric.<ref name='Policansky'>{{cite journal | title=Sex change in plants and animals | journal=Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics | year=1982 | first=D. | last=Policansky | volume=13 | pages=471–495 | doi=10.1146/annurev.es.13.110182.002351}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| author=Russell-Hunter, W. D. |author2=McMahon, R. F.| date=1976| title=Evidence for functional protandry in a fresh-water basommatophoran limpet, ''Laevapex fuscus''| journal=Transactions of the American Microscopical Society| volume=95| number=2| pages=174–182| jstor=3225061| doi=10.2307/3225061}}</ref> * ''[[Speyeria mormonia]]'', or the Mormon Fritillary, is a butterfly species exhibiting protandry. In its case, functional protandry refers to the emergence of male adults 2–3 weeks before female adults.<ref>Sculley, Colleen E., and Carol L. Boggs. "Mating systems and sexual division of foraging effort affect puddling behaviour by butterflies." ''Ecological Entomology'' 21.2 (1996): 193-197</ref>
===Protogyny=== [[File:Thalassoma lunare 1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Moon wrasse]], ''Thalassoma lunare'', a protogynous animal species]]
Protogynous hermaphrodites are animals that are born female and at some point in their lifespan change sex to male. As the animal ages, based on internal or external triggers, it shifts sex to become a male animal. Male [[fecundity]] increases greatly with age, unlike female.
Protogyny is the most common form of hermaphroditism in fish in nature.<ref name='Avise'>{{cite journal | title=Evolutionary Perspectives on Hermaphroditism in Fishes | journal=Sexual Development | year=2009 | first=JC | last=Avise |author2=JE Mank | volume=3 | pages=152–163| id=| doi=10.1159/000223079}}</ref> About 75% of the 500 known sequentially hermaphroditic fish species are protogynous.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pauly|first1=Daniel|title=Darwin's Fishes: An Encyclopedia of Ichthyology, Ecology, and Evolution|date=2004|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781139451819|page=108|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lTDa0fM4vQIC|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Pandian|first=TJ|title=Genetic Sex Differentiation in Fish|year=2012|publisher=Science Publishers|location=Boca Raton, FL}}</ref> Common model organisms for this type of sequential hermaphroditism are [[wrasses]]. They are one of the largest families of coral reef fish and belong to the family Labridae. Wrasses are found around the world in all marine habitats and tend to bury themselves in sand at night or when they feel threatened.<ref name='Animal Planet'>{{cite web | url=http://animal.discovery.com/guides/fish/marine/wrasseintro.html | title=Animal Planet :: Fish Guide -- Wrasse | accessdate=2011-03-28 | publisher=PetEducation.com}}</ref> In wrasses, the larger of the two fish is the male, while the smaller is the female. In most cases, females and immature have a uniform color while the male has the terminal bicolored phase.<ref name='Warner R'/> Large males hold territories and try to pair spawn while small to mid-size initial-phase males live with females and group [[Spawn (biology)|spawn]].<ref name='Adreani'>{{cite journal | title=Mating system and reproductive biology of a temperate wrasse, ''Halichoeres semicinctus'' | journal=Copeia | year=2008 | first=M. S. | last=Adreani |author2=Allen, L. G. | pages=467–475 | doi=10.1643/cp-06-265 | volume=2008}}</ref> In other words, both the initial and terminal phase males can breed; however, they differ in the way they do it.
In the [[California sheephead]] (''Semicossyphus pulcher''), a type of wrasse, when the female changes to male, the ovaries degenerate and spermatogenic crypts appear in the gonads. The general structure of the gonads remains ovarian after the transformation and the sperm is transported through a series of ducts on the periphery of the gonad and [[oviduct]]. Here sex change is age-dependent. For example, the California sheephead stays a female for four years before changing sex.<ref name='Warner R'>{{cite journal | title=The reproductive biology of the Protogynous hermaphrodite Pimelometopon Pulchrum (Pisces: Labridae). | journal=Fishery Bulletin | year=1975 | first=R.R | last=Warner | volume=73 | pages=261–283| id=}}</ref>
[[Thalassoma bifasciatum|Blue-headed wrasse]] begin life as males or females, but females can change sex and function as males. Young females and males start with a distinct coloration known as the "Initial Phase" before progressing into the "Terminal Phase" coloration, which has a change in intensity of color, stripes, and bars. Initial Phase males have larger [[testes]] than larger, terminal phase males, which enables the initial phase males to produce a large amount of sperm. This strategy is able to compete with that of the larger male, who is able to guard his own harem.
''[[Botryllus schlosseri]]'', a colonial [[tunicate]], is a protogynous hermaphrodite. In a colony, eggs are released about two days before the peak of sperm emission.<ref name="pmid25044771">{{cite journal |author1=Gasparini F |author2=Manni L. |author3=Cima F. |author4=Zaniolo G |author5=Burighel P |author6=Caicci F |author7=Franchi N |author8=Schiavon F |author9=Rigon F |author10=Campagna D |author11=Ballarin L |title=Sexual and asexual reproduction in the colonial ascidian Botryllus schlosseri |journal=Genesis |volume= 53|issue= |pages= 105–20| date=July 2014 |pmid=25044771 |doi=10.1002/dvg.22802 |url=}}</ref> Although self-fertilization is avoided and cross-fertilization favored by this strategy, self-fertilization is still possible. Self-fertilized eggs develop with a substantially higher frequency of anomalies during cleavage than cross-fertilized eggs (23% vs. 1.6%).<ref name="pmid25044771" /> Also a significantly lower percentage of larvae derived from self-fertilized eggs metamorphose, and the growth of the colonies derived from their metamorphosis is significantly lower. These findings suggest that self-fertilization gives rise to inbreeding depression associated with developmental deficits that are likely caused by expression of deleterious recessive mutations.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Bernstein | first1=H. | last2=Hopf | first2=F. A. | last3=Michod | first3=RE | year=1987 | title=The molecular basis of the evolution of sex | journal=Adv Genet | volume=24 | pages=323–70 | pmid=3324702 | doi=10.1016/S0065-2660(08)60012-7}}</ref>
Other examples of protogynous organisms include: * In the following [[fish]] families: [[Serranidae]] (groupers),<ref name="grouper">{{cite web|url=http://www.fishbase.org/summary/FamilySummary.php?id=289&lang=german|title=Familie Serranidae - Sea basses: groupers and fairy basslets |date=August 26, 2010|publisher=Fishbase|accessdate=January 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name="rk">{{cite web|url=http://reefkeeping.com/issues/2005-04/ac/index.php|title=Anthiinae - the Fancy Basses|year=2008|publisher=Reefkeeping Magazine|accessdate=January 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name="rt">{{cite book|author1=R. Thompson |author2=J.L. Munro |lastauthoramp=yes |editor =J. L. Munro|title =Caribbean Coral Reef Fishery Resources|chapter =The Biology, Ecology and Bionomics of the Hinds and Groupers, Serranidae|publisher =The WorldFish Center|year =1983|page=62|isbn =978-971-10-2201-3|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=yuGjAS0kwlgC&lpg=PA62&dq=protogynous%20hermaphroditism%20animals&pg=PA62#v=onepage&q=protogynous%20hermaphroditism%20animals&f=false}}</ref> [[Sparidae]] (porgies), [[Synbranchidae]] (swamp eels),<ref name="gold">{{cite book|author=J. R. Gold |editor =W. S. Hoar |editor2=D.J. Randall |editor3=J. R. Brett|title =Bioenergetics and Growth|chapter =Cytogenetics|publisher =Academic Press|series =Fish Physiology|volume=VIII|year =1979|page=358|isbn =978-0-12-350408-1|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=CB1qu2VbKwQC&lpg=PA358&dq=protogynous%20hermaphroditism%20animals&pg=PA358#v=onepage&q=protogynous%20hermaphroditism%20animals&f=false}}</ref> [[Labridae]] (wrasses), [[Scaridae]] (parrotfishes), [[Pomacanthidae]] (angelfishes), [[Gobiidae]] (gobies), [[Elacatinus]], [[Lethrinidae]] (emperors), and possibly others.<ref name="pavlov">{{cite book|author1=Dimitri A. Pavlov |author2=Natal'ya G. Emel'yanova |author3=Georgij G. Novikov |last-author-amp=yes |editor =Tore Jakobsen |editor2=Michael J. Fogarty |editor3=Bernard A. Megrey |editor4=Erlend Moksness|title =Fish Reproductive Biology: Implications for Assessment and Management|chapter =Reproductive Dynamics|publisher =John Wiley and Sons|year =2009|page=60|isbn =978-1-4051-2126-2|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=k5uXmgJVaRIC&lpg=PA60&dq=protogynous%20hermaphroditism%20occurs%20in%20the%20family&pg=PA60#v=onepage&q=protogynous%20hermaphroditism%20occurs%20in%20the%20family&f=false}}</ref>
* The [[isopod]]s ''[[Cyathura]] polita'' and ''C. carinata'' * The [[tanaidacea]]n ''[[Heterotanais]] oerstedi''. * The echinoderms, ''[[Asterina (starfish)|Asterina pancerii]] '' and ''A. gibbosa'' are also protogynous and they brood their young. * Protogyny sometimes occurs in the frog ''[[Rana temporaria]]'', where old females sometimes change to males.<ref name='Policansky'/>
{{anchor|Size-advantage model}}
===Ultimate causes===
The [[proximate and ultimate causation|ultimate cause]] of a biological phenomenon concerns why that phenomenon makes organisms better adapted to their environment, and thus why evolution by natural selection has produced that phenomenon. This is in contrast to proximate causes, which concern the molecular and physiological mechanisms that produce the phenomenon. A number of ultimate causes of hermaphroditism have been proposed, of which two are most relevant to sequential hermaphroditism.<ref name='Ghiselin'>{{cite journal | title=The evolution of hermaphroditism among animals | journal=The Quarterly Review of Biology | year=1969 | first=Michael T. |authorlink=Michael Ghiselin | last=Ghiselin | volume=44 | pages=189–208| id=| pmid=4901396 | issue=2 | doi=10.1086/406066}}</ref>
The 'size-advantage model' states that individuals of a given sex reproduce more effectively if they are a certain size or age. To create selection for sequential hermaphroditism, small individuals must have higher reproductive fitness as one sex and larger individuals must have higher reproductive fitness as the opposite sex. For example, eggs are larger than sperm, thus larger individuals are able to make more eggs, so individuals could maximize their reproductive potential by beginning life as male and then turning female upon achieving a certain size.<ref name='Ghiselin'></ref>
Sequential hermaphroditism can also protect against inbreeding in populations of organisms that have low enough motility and/or are sparsely distributed enough that there is a considerable risk of siblings encountering each other after reaching sexual maturity, and interbreeding. If siblings are all the same or similar ages, and if they all begin life as one sex and then transition to the other sex at about the same age, then siblings are highly likely to be the same sex at any given time. This should dramatically reduce the likelihood of inbreeding. Both protandry and protogyny are known to help prevent inbreeding in plants,{{cn|date=October 2018}} and many examples of sequential hermaphroditism attributable to inbreeding prevention have been identified in a wide variety of animals.<ref name='Ghiselin'></ref>
In most [[ectotherms]] body size and female fecundity are positively correlated.<ref name='Warner'>{{cite journal | title=The Adaptive Significance of Sequential Hermaphroditism in Animals. | journal=The American Naturalist | year=1975 | first=R. R. | last=Warner | volume=109 | pages=61–82| id=| doi=10.1086/282974}}</ref> This supports the size-advantage model. Kazancioglu and Alonzo (2010) performed the first comparative analysis of sex change in [[Labridae]]. Their analysis supports the size-advantage model and suggest that sequential hermaphroditism is correlated to the size-advantage. They determined that [[dioecy]] was less likely to occur when the size advantage is stronger than other advantages<ref name='Alonzo'>{{cite journal | title=A comparative analysis of sex change in Labridae supports the size advantage hypothesis | journal=Evolution; international journal of organic evolution | year=2010 | first=E | last=Kazancioğlu |author2=SH Alonzo | volume=64 | pages=2254–64| id=| pmid=20394662 | doi=10.1111/j.1558-5646.2010.01016.x | issue=8}}</ref> Warner suggests that selection for protandry may occur in populations where female fecundity is augmented with age and individuals mate randomly. Selection for protogyny may occur where there are traits in the population that depress male fecundity at early ages (territoriality, mate selection or inexperience) and when female fecundity is decreased with age, the latter seems to be rare in the field.<ref name='Warner'/> An example of territoriality favoring protogyny occurs when there is a need to protect their habitat and being a large male is advantageous for this purpose. In the mating aspect, a large male has a higher chance of mating, while this has no effect on the female mating fitness.<ref name='Alonzo'/> Thus, he suggests that female fecundity has more impact on sequential hermaphroditism than the age structures of the population.<ref name='Warner'/>
The size-advantage model predicts that sex change would only be absent if the relationship between size/age with reproductive potential is identical in both sexes. With this prediction one would assume that hermaphroditism is very common, but this is not the case. Sequential hermaphroditism is very rare and according to scientists this is due to some cost that decreases fitness in sex changers as opposed to those who don’t change sex. Some of the hypotheses proposed for the dearth of hermaphrodites are the energetic cost of sex change, genetic and/or physiological barriers to sex change, and sex-specific mortality rates.<ref name='Warner' /><ref name='Charnov'>{{cite journal | title=Size Advantage May Not Always Favor Sex Change | journal=Journal of Theoretical Biology | year=1986 | first=E | last=Charnov | volume=119 | pages=283–285| id=| pmid= | doi= 10.1016/s0022-5193(86)80141-2| issue=}}</ref><ref name='Munday'>{{cite journal | title=The energetic cost of protogynous versus protandrous sex change in the bi-directional sex changing fish Gobiodon histrio | journal=Marine Biology | year=2002 | first=P | last=Munday|author2=BW Molony | volume=141 | pages=429–446| id=| pmid= | doi= 10.1007/s00227-002-0904-8| issue=}}</ref>
In 2009, Kazanciglu and Alonzo found that dioecy was only favored when the cost of changing sex was very large. This indicates that the cost of sex change does not explain the rarity of sequential hermaphroditism by itself.<ref name='Kazancioğlu'>{{cite journal | title=Costs of changing sex do not explain why sequential hermaphroditism is rare | journal=The American Naturalist | year=2009 | first=E | last=Kazancioğlu |author2=SH Alonzo | volume=173 | pages=327–36| id=| pmid=19199519 | doi=10.1086/596539 | issue=3}}</ref>
===Proximate causes===
Many studies have focused on the proximate causes of sequential hermaphroditism. The role of [[aromatase]] has been widely studied in this area. Aromatase is an [[enzyme]] that controls the [[androgen]]/[[estrogen]] ratio in animals by catalyzing the conversion of [[testosterone]] into [[oestradiol]], which is irreversible. It has been discovered that the aromatase pathway mediates sex change in both directions.<ref name='Kroon'>{{cite journal | title=Aromatase pathway mediates sex change in each direction. | journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]] | year=2005 | first=F. J. | last=Kroon |author2= Munday, P. L. |author3=Westcott, D. |author4=Hobbs, J.-P. |author5=Liley, N. R. | volume=272 | pages=1399–405 | pmc=1560338 | pmid=16006326 | doi=10.1098/rspb.2005.3097 | issue=1570}}</ref> Many studies also involve understanding the effect of aromatase inhibitors on sex change. One such study was performed by Kobayashi et al. In their study they tested the role of estrogens in male three-spot wrasses (''Halichoeres trimaculatus''). They discovered that fish treated with aromatase inhibitors showed decreased gonodal weight, plasma estrogen level and spermatogonial proliferation in the testis as well as increased androgen levels. Their results suggest that estrogens are important in the regulation of [[spermatogenesis]] in this protogynous hermaphrodite.<ref name='Kobayashi'>{{cite journal | title=Role of estrogen in spermatogenesis in initial phase males of the three-spot wrasse (''Halichoeres trimaculatus''): wffect of aromatase inhibitor on the testis. | journal=Developmental Dynamics | year=2011 | first=y | last=Kobayashi |author2=Nozu R |author3=Nakamura M. | volume=240 | pages=116–121| id=| url=https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-78650344417&partnerID=40&md5=847189402b2dcdb18259e2dc89206111 | accessdate=2011-04-27 | doi=10.1002/dvdy.22507 | pmid=21117145}}</ref>
===Genetic consequences===
Sequential hermaphrodites almost always have a sex ratio biased towards the birth sex, and consequently experience significantly more reproductive success after switching sexes. In theory, this should decrease [[genetic diversity]] and [[effective population size]] (Ne). However, a study of two ecologically similar [[Cheimerius|santer sea bream]] ([[gonochoric]]) and [[Chrysoblephus puniceus|slinger sea bream]] (protogynous) in South African waters found that genetic diversities were similar in the two species, and while Ne was lower in the instant for the sex-changer, they were similar over a relatively short time horizion.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Coscia |first1=I. |last2=Chopelet|first2=J. |last3=Waples|first3=R. S. |last4=Mann|first4=B. Q. |last5=Mariani|first5=S. |date=2016 |title=Sex change and effective population size: implications for population genetic studies in marine fish|url=http://usir.salford.ac.uk/39110/|journal=Heredity |volume=117 |pages=251–258 |doi=10.1038/hdy.2016.50 |accessdate=5 January 2017|via=}}</ref>
==Botany==
=== Flowering plants === [[File:Aeonium protandry.jpg|thumb|Protandrous flowers of ''[[Aeonium undulatum]]'']] In the context of the [[plant sexuality]] of flowering plants (angiosperms), there are two forms of dichogamy: '''''protogyny'''''—female function precedes male function—and '''''protandry'''''—male function precedes female function.
Historically, dichogamy has been regarded as a mechanism for reducing [[inbreeding]].<ref name=Darwin1862>{{cite book |author=Darwin, Charles |title=On the various contrivances by which British and foreign orchids are fertilized by insects, and on the good effects of intercrossing |publisher=John Murray |location=London |year=1862 |url=http://pages.britishlibrary.net/charles.darwin3/orchids/orchids_fm.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060215011429/http://pages.britishlibrary.net/charles.darwin3/orchids/orchids_fm.htm |archivedate=2006-02-15 |df= }}</ref> However, a survey of the angiosperms found that [[self-incompatibility in plants|self-incompatible]] (SI) plants, which are incapable of inbreeding, were as likely to be dichogamous as were self-compatible (SC) plants.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/2445372 |author=Bertin, R.I. |title=Incidence of monoecy and dichogamy in relation to self-fertilization in angiosperms |journal=Am. J. Bot. |volume=80 |issue=5 |pages=557–60 |year=1993 |jstor=2445372}}</ref> This finding led to a reinterpretation of dichogamy as a more general mechanism for reducing the impact of [[pollen]]-[[Carpel|pistil]] interference on pollen import and export.<ref name=LloydWebb1986>{{cite journal |author=Lloyd, D. G., Webb, C. J. |title=The avoidance of interference between the presentation of pollen and stigmas in angiosperms: I. Dichogamy |journal=New Zeal. J. Bot. |volume=24 |pages=135–62 |year=1986 |doi=10.1080/0028825x.1986.10409725}}</ref><ref name=Barrett2002>{{cite journal |author=Barrett, S. C. |title=Sexual interference of the floral kind |journal=Heredity |volume=88 |issue=2 |pages=154–9 |date=February 2002 |pmid=11932774 |doi=10.1038/sj.hdy.6800020}}</ref> Unlike the [[inbreeding avoidance]] hypothesis, which focused on female function, this interference-avoidance hypothesis considers both reproductive functions.
In many hermaphroditic species, the close physical proximity of [[anthers]] and [[Carpel|stigma]] makes interference unavoidable, either within a [[flower]] or between flowers on an [[inflorescence]]. Within-flower interference, which occurs when either the pistil interrupts pollen removal or the anthers prevent pollen deposition, can result in autonomous or facilitated self-pollination.<ref name=LloydSchoen1992>{{cite journal |doi=10.1086/297040 |author=Lloyd, D. G., Schoen D. J. |title=Self- and Cross-Fertilization in Plants. I. Functional Dimensions |journal=International Journal of Plant Sciences |volume=153 |issue=3, Part 1 |pages=358–69 |date=September 1992}}</ref><ref name=LloydWebb1986/> Between-flower interference results from similar mechanisms, except that the interfering structures occur on different flowers within the same inflorescence and it requires [[pollinator]] activity. This results in [[geitonogamy|geitonogamous]] pollination, the transfer of pollen between flowers of the same individual.<ref name=deJong1993>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0169-5347(93)90239-L |author=de Jong, T. J.; Waser, N. M.; Klinkhamer, P.G.L. |title=Geitonogamy: the neglected side of selfing |journal=Trends Ecol. Evol. |volume=8 |pages=321–25 |year=1993 }}</ref><ref name=LloydSchoen1992/> In contrast to within-flower interference, geitonogamy necessarily involves the same processes as outcrossing: pollinator attraction, reward provisioning, and pollen removal. Therefore, between-flower interference not only carries the cost of self-fertilization ([[inbreeding depression]]<ref name=Schemske1980>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/2408218 |author=Schemske, D.W. |title=Evolution of floral display in the orchid ''Brassavola nodosa'' |journal=Evolution |volume=34 |issue=3 |pages=489–91 |year=1980 |jstor=2408218}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1146/annurev.es.18.110187.001321 |author=Charlesworth, D.; Charlesworth, B. |title=Inbreeding Depression and its Evolutionary Consequences |journal=Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics |volume=18 |pages=237–68 |year=1987 |jstor=2097132}}</ref>), but also reduces the amount of pollen available for export (so-called "pollen discounting"<ref name="Harder, L. D.; Wilson, W. G. 684–95">{{cite journal |doi=10.1086/286199 |author=Harder, L. D.; Wilson, W. G. |title=A Clarification of Pollen Discounting and Its Joint Effects with Inbreeding Depression on Mating System Evolution |journal=The American Naturalist |volume=152 |issue=5 |pages=684–95 |date=November 1998 |pmid=18811343 |jstor=2463846}}</ref>). Because pollen discounting diminishes outcross siring success, interference avoidance may be an important evolutionary force in floral biology.<ref name="Harder, L. D.; Wilson, W. G. 684–95"/><ref name=HarderBarrett1996/><ref name=Barrett2002/><ref>{{cite journal |author=Harder, L. D.; Barrett, S. C. H. |title=Mating cost of large floral displays in hermaphrodite plants |journal=Nature |volume=373 |issue=6514 |pages=512–5 |date=February 1995 |doi=10.1038/373512a0 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v373/n6514/abs/373512a0.html}}</ref> Dichogamy may reduce between-flower interference by minimizing the temporal overlap between stigma and anthers within an inflorescence. Large inflorescences attract more pollinators, potentially enhancing reproductive success by increasing pollen import and export.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/1940537 |author=Geber, M. |title=The Relationship of Plant Size to Self-Pollination in ''Mertensia ciliata'' |journal=Ecology |volume=66 |issue=3 |pages=762–72 |year=1985 |jstor=1940537}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1098/rspb.1985.0031 |author=Bell G. |title=On the function of flowers |journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]] |volume=224 |pages=223–65 |year=1985 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/305706a0 |author=Queller, D.C. |title=Sexual selection in a hermaphroditic plant |journal=Nature |volume=305 |pages=706–707 |year=1983 |issue=5936|url=https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/62650/1/305706a0.pdf }}</ref><ref name=Schemske1980/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3565970 |author=Klinkhamer, P. G. L., de Jong, T. J. |title=Effects of plant size, plant density and sex differential nectar reward on pollinator visitation in the protandrous ''Echium vulgare'' |journal=Oikos |volume=57 |issue=3 |pages=399–405 |year=1990 |jstor=3565970}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3565669 |author=Schmid-Hempel, P., Speiser, B. |title=Effects of inflorescence size on pollination in ''Epilobium angustifolium'' |journal=Oikos |volume=53 |issue=1 |pages=98–104 |year=1988 |jstor=3565669}}</ref> However, large inflorescences also increase the opportunities for both geitonogamy and pollen discounting, so that the opportunity for between-flower interference increases with inflorescence size.<ref name=HarderBarrett1996>{{cite book |author=Harder, L. D.; Barrett, S. C. H. |chapter=Pollen dispersal and mating patterns in animal-pollinated plants |editor=Lloyd, D. G. |editor2=Barrett, S. C. H. |title=Floral Biology: Studies on Floral Evolution in Animal-Pollinated Plants |publisher=Chapman & Hall |year=1996 |pages=140–190 }}</ref> Consequently, the evolution of floral display size may represent a compromise between maximizing pollinator visitation and minimizing geitonogamy and pollen discounting (Barrett et al., 1994).<ref>{{cite book |author=Holsinger K.E. |chapter=Pollination biology and the evolution of mating systems in flowering plants |editor=Hecht, M.K. |title=Evolutionary Biology |publisher=Plenum Press |location=NY |year=1996 |pages=107–149 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3545212 |author=Klinkhamer, P. G. L., de Jong, T. J. |title=Attractiveness to pollinators: a plant’s dilemma |journal=Oikos |volume=66 |issue=1 |pages=180–4 |year=1993 |jstor=3545212}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Snow, A.A., Spira, T.P., Simpson, R., Klips, R.A. |chapter=The ecology of geitonogamous pollination |editor=Lloyd, D.G. |editor2=Barrett, S.C.H. |title=Floral Biology: Studies on Floral Evolution in Animal-Pollinated Plants |publisher=Chapman & Hall |location=NY |year=1996 |pages=191–216 }}</ref>
Protandry may be particularly relevant to this compromise, because it often results in an inflorescence structure with female phase flowers positioned below male phase flowers.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF02856676 |author1=Bertin, R. I. |author2=Newman, C. M. |title=Dichogamy in angiosperms |journal=Bot. Rev. |volume=59 |pages=112–52 |year=1993 }}</ref> Given the tendency of many insect pollinators to forage upwards through inflorescences,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2311.1985.tb00530.x |author=Galen, C.; Plowright, R.C. |title=Contrasting movement patterns of nectar-collecting and pollen-collecting bumble bees (''Bombus terricola'') on fireweed (''Chamaenerion angustifolium'') inflorescences |journal=Ecol. Entomol. |volume=10 |pages=9–17 |year=1988 }}</ref> protandry may enhance pollen export by reducing between-flower interference.<ref name=Harderetal2000>{{cite journal |author1=Harder, L. D. |author2=Barrett, S. C. |author3=Cole, W. W. |title=The mating consequences of sexual segregation within inflorescences of flowering plants |journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]]|volume=267 |issue=1441 |pages=315–320 |date=February 2000 |pmid=10722210 |pmc=1690540 |doi=10.1098/rspb.2000.1002 |url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=10722210}}</ref><ref name=Darwin1862/> Furthermore, this enhanced pollen export should increase as floral display size increases, because between-flower interference should increase with floral display size. These effects of protandry on between-flower interference may decouple the benefits of large inflorescences from the consequences of geitonogamy and pollen discounting. Such a decoupling would provide a significant reproductive advantage through increased pollinator visitation and siring success.
Harder et al. (2000) demonstrated experimentally that dichogamy both reduced rates of self-fertilization and enhanced outcross siring success through reductions in geitonogamy and pollen discounting, respectively.<ref name=Harderetal2000/> Routley & Husband (2003) examined the influence of inflorescence size on this siring advantage and found a bimodal distribution with increased siring success with both small and large display sizes.<ref name=RoutleyHusband2003>{{cite journal |author1=Routley, M. B. |author2=Husband, B. C. |title=The effect of protandry on siring success in ''Chamerion angustifolium'' (Onagraceae) with different inflorescence sizes |journal=Evolution |volume=57 |issue=2 |pages=240–248 |date=February 2003 |pmid=12683521 |doi=10.1554/0014-3820(2003)057[0240:teopos]2.0.co;2}} </ref>
The length of stigmatic receptivity plays a key role in regulating the isolation of the male and female stages in dichogamous plants, and stigmatic receptivity can be influenced by both temperature and humidity.<ref name=Lora>{{cite journal | title=Stigmatic receptivity in a dichogamous early-divergent angiosperm species, ''Annona cherimola'' (Annonaceae): Influence of temperature and humidity. | journal=American Journal of Botany | year=2011 | first=J. | last=Lora |author2=Herrero, M. |author3=Hormaza, J. I. | volume=98 | pages=265–274 | url=http://www.amjbot.org/cgi/doi/10.3732/ajb.1000185 | doi=10.3732/ajb.1000185 | pmid=21613115}}</ref> Another study by Jersakova and Johnson, studied the effects of protandry on the pollination process of the moth pollinated orchid, ''Satyrium longicauda''. They discovered that protandry tended to reduce the absolute levels of self-pollination and suggest that the evolution of protandry could be driven by the consequences of the pollination process for male mating success.<ref name=Jersakova>{{cite journal | title=Protandry promotes male pollination success in a moth-pollinated orchid. | journal=Functional Ecology | year=2007 | first=J. | last=Jersáková |author2=SD Johnson | volume=21 | pages=496–504 | url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1365-2435.2007.01256. | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2435.2007.01256.x}}</ref> Another study that indicated that dichogamy might increase male pollination success was by Dai and Galloway.<ref name=Dai>{{cite journal | title=Do dichogamy and herkogamy reduce sexual interference in a self-incompatible species? | journal=Functional Ecology | year=2011 | first=C. | last=Dai |author2=Galloway, L. F. | volume=25 | pages=271–278| url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1365-2435.2010.01795 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2435.2010.01795.x}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Snoh Aalegra | image = Snoh Aalegra 2016.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Aalegra performing in [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]], during the REC. Festival, in November 2016 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Snoh Nowrozi | alias = {{hlist|Sheri|Sheri Nowrozi}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|09|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Uppsala]], [[Sweden]] | origin = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | genre = {{hlist|[[Pop music|Pop]]|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]|[[Soul music|Soul]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}} | instrument = Vocals | years_active = 2001–present | label = {{hlist|[[Sony Music|Sony Music Sweden]]|Mamia|[[Universal Music Sweden]]|[[Epic Records|Epic]]|[[No I.D.#ARTium Recordings|ARTium]]|[[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]]}} | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[No I.D.]]|[[Common (rapper)|Common]]|[[Vince Staples]]|[[RZA]]|[[Killer Mike]]|[[Vic Mensa]]|[[Timbuktu (musician)|Timbuktu]]|[[Drake]]||[[James Fauntleroy]]}} | website = {{URL|https://snohaalegra.com}} }} '''Snoh Nowrozi''' (born 13 September 1987), known professionally as '''Snoh Aalegra''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|n|oʊ|ˈ|æ|l|i|ɡ|r|ɑː}}), is a [[Swedes|Swedish]] singer and songwriter. ==Early life== Snoh Nowrozi was born on 13 September 1987 in [[Uppsala]], [[Sweden]] to [[Persian people|Persian]] parents. She grew up in [[Enköping]], [[Sweden]].{{cite web |title=First Look Friday: Snoh Aalegra's Fresh Take On R&B |url=http://www.okayplayer.com/news/new-artist-snoh-aalegra-photos-interview.html |website=Okayplayer |accessdate=15 October 2018 |date=16 January 2015}}{{cite web |last1=Erwik |first1=Alexander |title=Sheri - nästa års stora svenska stjärna - Finest.se |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228222346/http://www.finest.se/articles/article.php?aid=2306/ |website=Finest.se |accessdate=11 October 2018 |date=10 December 2008 |language=Swedish}}{{cite web |last1=Ijaduola |first1=Deborah |title=Snoh Aalegra: on connecting the dots of her Swedish-Persian heritage |url=http://gal-dem.com/snoh-aalegra-swedish-persian-heritage/ |website=[[gal-dem]] |accessdate=7 October 2018 |date=17 November 2017}} ==Career== ===2001–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, ''First Sign''=== [[File:Sheri 2009.jpg|thumb|190px|Aalegra at [[Stockholm Pride]] in 2009]] In 2001, Aalegra signed to [[Sony Music|Sony Music Sweden]] at the age of 14, but no music was released though the deal. Aalegra said "things didn't really work out with [Sony Sweden], but I'm glad I had the opportunity to be exposed to the industry at a young age."{{cite web |last1=Brara |first1=Noor |title=Discovery: Snoh Aalegra - Interview Magazine |url=https://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/discover-snoh-aalegra |website=Interview Magazine |accessdate=12 October 2018 |date=24 November 2014}}{{cite web |last1=Shouneyia |first1=Alexa |title=Snoh Aalegra Talks New Album 'Feels,' Working With No I.D. & the Best Advice She Received From Prince |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8014782/snoh-aalegra-interview-new-album-feels-prince-no-id |website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=7 October 2018 |date=26 October 2017}} In 2009, Aalegra began working on her debut album for Mamia Music, though [[Universal Music Sweden]]. Aalegra began her music career as Sheri, with the release of her debut single, "Hit And Run" on 16 February 2009, with production by [[Andreas Carlsson]]. The single peaked at number 12 on the [[Sverigetopplistan|Swedish Single Charts]].{{cite web |last1=Hung |first1=Steffen |title=swedishcharts.com - Sheri - Hit And Run |url=https://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Sheri&titel=Hit+And+Run&cat=s |website=swedishcharts.com |accessdate=11 October 2018}} Aalegra released her second single "U Got Me Good" on 4 December 2009, which peaked at number 2 on the Swedish Single Charts.{{cite web |last1=Hung |first1=Steffen |title=swedishcharts.com - Sheri - U Got Me Good |url=https://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Sheri&titel=U+Got+Me+Good&cat=s |website=swedishcharts.com |accessdate=11 October 2018}} On 1 January 2010, Aalegra release her first studio album ''First Sign'', which features a cover of the 1984 song, "[[Smooth Operator]]" by [[Sade (band)|Sade]]. The album also includes her first two single, "Hit And Run" and "U Got Me Good". ===2014–present: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, ''Feels''=== In July 2014, Aalegra debut her new name, Snoh Aalegra, and appeared on [[Common (rapper)|Common]]'s tenth studio album, ''[[Nobody's Smiling]]''. She released her debut EP, ''There Will Be Sunshine'' on 17 November 2014 through [[Epic Records]]. The EP includes "Bad Things" featuring [[Common (rapper)|Common]] and "Stockholm, Pt. II (Outro)" featuring [[Cocaine 80s]].{{cite web |title=There Will Be Sunshine - EP by Snoh Aalegra |url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/there-will-be-sunshine-ep/938986790 |accessdate=7 October 2018 |date=17 November 2014}} On 11 February 2015, Aalegra released her first single as Snoh Aalegra, "Emotional", with production by [[RZA]]. She also appeared on [[Vince Staples]]' ''[[Summertime '06]]'' in June 2015, providing vocals for the song "Jump Off the Road". Aalegra signed with [[No I.D.]]'s [[No I.D.#ARTium Recordings|ARTium Recordings]] in 2016 and released an EP, ''Don't Explain'' on 8 April 2016, with features and production from [[James Fauntleroy]], [[No I.D.]], [[Boi-1da]], [[Christian Rich]] and [[DJ Dahi]]. The EP features a cover of the 1944 song, "[[Don't Explain (song)#Notable cover versions|Don't Explain]]" by [[Billie Holiday]] and [[Arthur Herzog Jr.]]. In 2017, Aalegra released her debut album, ''Feels'', with features from [[Vince Staples]], [[Vic Mensa]], and [[Timbuktu (musician)|Timbuktu]]. Her song from the album, "Time" was sampled on [[Drake (musician)|Drake]]’s ''[[More Life]]'' song "Do Not Disturb" and on September 12, 2018, her song "Nothing Burns Like the Cold" featuring Vince Staples, was used by [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] for their [[iPhone XS]] announcement video and commercials.{{cite web |title=iPhone XS — Illusion — Apple |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l96MQKwwHOE |website=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=7 October 2018 |date=15 September 2018}}{{cite web |title=Apple iPhone XS TV Commercial, 'Illusion' Song by Snoh Aalegra, Vince Staples |url=https://www.ispot.tv/ad/djH1/apple-iphone-xs-illusion-song-by-snoh-aalegra |website=iSpot.tv |accessdate=7 October 2018 |language=en}} ==Personal life== Aalegra briefly moved from [[Stockholm]] to [[London]] before moving to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], where she has resided since 2012.{{cite web |last1=Weston |first1=Liana |title=Sound Scout: Meet Snoh Aalegra, the Enchanting Soulstress With a Hypnotic Voice |url=https://www.teenvogue.com/story/snoh-aalegra-interview |website=Teen Vogue |accessdate=7 October 2018 |language=en}} Aalegra speaks [[Persian language|Farsi]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]] and [[English language|English]]. ==Artistry== Aalegra cites [[James Brown]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[Whitney Houston]] and [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] as musical influences.{{cite web |last1=Walker |first1=Lily |title=New Noise: Snoh {{!}} Wonderland Magazine |url=https://www.wonderlandmagazine.com/2014/12/09/new-noise-snoh-2/ |website=Wonderland |accessdate=7 October 2018 |date=9 December 2014}} ==Discography== ===As Sheri=== ====Studio albums==== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" ! {{About|the medical therapy|the cell type|Stem cell}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} '''Stem-cell therapy''' is the use of [[stem cells]] to treat or prevent a disease or condition.<ref> {{cite journal |authors=Mahla RS| title = Stem cells application in regenerative medicine and disease threpeutics | journal = International Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 2016 | issue = 7 | pages = 1–24 | year = 2016 | pmid = 27516776 | doi = 10.1155/2016/6940283 | pmc=4969512}}</ref>
[[Bone marrow transplant]] is the most widely used stem-cell therapy, but some therapies derived from [[umbilical cord blood]] are also in use. Research is underway to develop various sources for stem cells, as well as to apply stem-cell treatments for [[neurodegenerative diseases]] and conditions such as [[diabetes]] and [[heart disease]], among others.
Stem-cell therapy has become controversial following developments such as the ability of scientists to isolate and culture [[embryonic stem cells]], to create stem cells using [[somatic cell nuclear transfer]] and their use of techniques to create [[induced pluripotent stem cells]]. This controversy is often related to [[abortion debate|abortion politics]] and to [[human cloning]]. Additionally, efforts to market treatments based on transplant of stored umbilical [[cord blood]] have been controversial.
{{TOC limit|3}}
==Medical uses== {{Further|Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation}} For over 30 years, [[bone marrow]] has been used to treat people with cancer with conditions such as [[leukaemia]] and [[lymphoma]]; this is the only form of stem-cell therapy that is widely practiced.<ref>Ian Murnaghan for Explore Stem Cells. Updated: 16 December 2013 [http://www.explorestemcells.co.uk/WhyPerformStemCellTransplant.html Why Perform a Stem Cell Transplant?]</ref><ref name=NCI>[http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Therapy/bone-marrow-transplant Bone Marrow Transplantation and Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation] In National Cancer Institute Fact Sheet web site. Bethesda, MD: National Institutes of Health, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2010. Cited 24 August 2010</ref><ref name="pmid18721775">{{cite journal | vauthors=Karanes C, Nelson GO, Chitphakdithai P, Agura E, Ballen KK, Bolan CD, Porter DL, Uberti JP, King RJ, Confer DL | title=Twenty years of unrelated donor hematopoietic cell transplantation for adult recipients facilitated by the National Marrow Donor Program | journal=Biology of Blood and Marrow Transplantation | volume=14 | issue=9 Suppl | year=2008 | pages=8–15 | doi= 10.1016/j.bbmt.2008.06.006 | pmid=18721775 }}</ref> During [[chemotherapy]], most growing cells are killed by the [[cytotoxic]] agents. These agents, however, cannot discriminate between the leukaemia or neoplastic cells, and the [[Hematopoiesis|hematopoietic stem cells]] within the bone marrow. It is this side effect of conventional chemotherapy strategies that the stem-cell transplant attempts to reverse; a donor's healthy bone marrow reintroduces functional stem cells to replace the cells lost in the host's body during treatment. The transplanted cells also generate an immune response that helps to kill off the cancer cells; this process can go too far, however, leading to [[graft vs host disease]], the most serious side effect of this treatment.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Malard F, Mohty M | year = 2014 | title = New Insight for the Diagnosis of Gastrointestinal Acute Graft-versus-Host Disease | journal = Mediators Inflamm | volume = 2014 | issue = | page = 701013 | doi = 10.1155/2014/701013 | pmid = 24733964 | pmc=3964897}}</ref>
Another stem-cell therapy called [[Prochymal]], was conditionally approved in Canada in 2012 for the management of acute graft-vs-host disease in children who are unresponsive to steroids.<ref name=mnt>{{cite news |url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/245704.php |title=Prochymal – First Stem Cell Drug Approved |date=22 May 2012 }}</ref> It is an [[Cell therapy#Allogeneic Cell Therapy|allogenic stem therapy]] based on [[mesenchymal stem cells]] (MSCs) derived from the bone marrow of adult donors. MSCs are purified from the marrow, cultured and packaged, with up to 10,000 doses derived from a single donor. The doses are stored frozen until needed.<ref name=NYT2012>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/18/health/a-stem-cell-based-drug-gets-approval-in-canada.html |title=A Stem-Cell-Based Drug Gets Approval in Canada |date=17 May 2012 }}</ref>
The FDA has approved five hematopoietic stem-cell products derived from umbilical cord blood, for the treatment of blood and immunological diseases.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Rosemann A | date = Dec 2014 | title = Why regenerative stem cell medicine progresses slower than expected | url = | journal = J Cell Biochem | volume = 115 | issue = 12| pages = 2073–76 | doi = 10.1002/jcb.24894 | pmid = 25079695 }}</ref>
In 2014, the [[European Medicines Agency]] recommended approval of [[limbal stem cell]]s for people with severe limbal stem cell deficiency due to burns in the eye.<ref name="ema">{{Cite web | title = First stem-cell therapy recommended for approval in EU | author = European Medicines Agency | date = | accessdate = 12 December 2014 | url = http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/news_and_events/news/2014/12/news_detail_002239.jsp&mid=WC0b01ac058004d5c1 }}</ref>
== Research == [[File:Stem cell treatments.svg|thumb|Diseases and conditions where stem cell treatment is promising or emerging.]] Stem cells are being studied for a number of reasons. The molecules and [[exosome (vesicle)|exosome]]s released from stem cells are also being studied in an effort to make medications.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maguire|first1=G|title=Therapeutics from Adult Stem Cells and the Hype Curve.|journal=ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters|date=12 May 2016|volume=7|issue=5|pages=441–43|pmid=27190588|doi=10.1021/acsmedchemlett.6b00125|pmc=4867479}}</ref> The [[Paracrine signalling|paracrine soluble factors]] produced by stem cells, known as the [[stem cell secretome]], has been found to be the predominant mechanism by which stem cell-based therapies mediate their effects in [[Degenerative disease|degenerative]], [[Autoimmune disease|auto-immune]] and [[Immune-mediated inflammatory diseases|inflammatory]] diseases.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Teixeira|first=Fábio G.|last2=Carvalho|first2=Miguel M.|last3=Sousa|first3=Nuno|last4=Salgado|first4=António J.|date=2013-10-01|title=Mesenchymal stem cells secretome: a new paradigm for central nervous system regeneration?|journal=Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences|language=en|volume=70|issue=20|pages=3871–3882|doi=10.1007/s00018-013-1290-8|pmid=23456256|issn=1420-682X}}</ref>
===Applications=== ====Neurodegeneration==== Research has been conducted on the effects of stem cells on animal models of [[Neurodegeneration|brain degeneration]], such as in [[Parkinson's disease|Parkinson's]], [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]], and [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref name="NIH">[http://stemcells.nih.gov/info/basics/pages/basics6.aspx Cell Basics: What are the potential uses of human stem cells and the obstacles that must be overcome before these potential uses will be realized?]. In Stem Cell Information World Wide Web site. Bethesda, MD: National Institutes of Health, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2009. cited Sunday, 26 April 2009</ref><ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/07/090720190726.htm Neural Stem Cells May Rescue Memory In Advanced Alzheimer's, Mouse Study Suggests<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/jama.285.13.1691 |author=Vastag B |title=Stem cells step closer to the clinic: paralysis partially reversed in rats with ALS-like disease |journal=JAMA |volume=285 |issue=13 |pages=1691–93 |date=April 2001 |pmid=11277806 |url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11277806}}</ref> There have been preliminary studies related to [[multiple sclerosis]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26524106 | doi=10.1111/imj.12944 | volume=46 | issue=1 | title=The role of autologous haemopoietic stem cell transplantation in the treatment of autoimmune disorders | year=2016 | journal=Intern Med J | pages=17–28 | author=Rebeiro P, Moore J}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.nationalmssociety.org/About-the-Society/News/Results-Reported-from-Case-Studies-of-Stem-Cell-Tr |title = Results Reported from Case Studies of Stem Cell Transplantation in People with Relapsing and Progressive MS |date = January 2015 |publisher = National MS Society }}</ref>
Healthy adult brains contain [[neural stem cell]]s which divide to maintain general stem-cell numbers, or become [[progenitor cells]]. In healthy adult laboratory animals, progenitor cells migrate within the brain and function primarily to maintain neuron populations for [[olfaction]] (the sense of smell). Pharmacological activation of [[endogenous]] neural stem cells has been reported to induce [[neuroprotection]] and behavioral recovery in adult rat models of neurological disorder.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Androutsellis-Theotokis A, Leker RR, Soldner F, etal |title=Notch signalling regulates stem cell numbers in vitro and in vivo |journal=Nature |volume=442 |issue=7104 |pages=823–26 |date=August 2006 |pmid=16799564 |doi=10.1038/nature04940 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Androutsellis-Theotokis A, Rueger MA, Park DM, etal |title=Targeting neural precursors in the adult brain rescues injured dopamine neurons |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=106 |issue=32 |pages=13570–75 |date=August 2009 |pmid=19628689 |pmc=2714762 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0905125106 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Androutsellis-Theotokis A, Rueger MA, Mkhikian H, Korb E, McKay RD |title=Signaling pathways controlling neural stem cells slow progressive brain disease |journal=Cold Spring Harb. Symp. Quant. Biol. |volume=73 |issue= |pages=403–10 |year=2008 |pmid=19022746 |doi=10.1101/sqb.2008.73.018 |url=}}</ref>
====Brain and spinal cord injury==== Stroke and [[traumatic brain injury]] lead to [[cell death]], characterized by a loss of neurons and [[oligodendrocytes]] within the brain. Clinical and animal studies have been conducted into the use of stem cells in cases of [[spinal cord injury]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kang KS, Kim SW, Oh YH, etal |title=A 37-year-old spinal cord-injured female patient, transplanted of multipotent stem cells from human UC blood, with improved sensory perception and mobility, both functionally and morphologically: a case study |journal=Cytotherapy |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=368–73 |year=2005 |pmid=16162459 |doi=10.1080/14653240500238160 |url=}}</ref><ref>Team co-headed by researchers at [[Chosun University]], [[Seoul National University]] and the [http://www.seoulcord.co.kr/bin/main.asp Seoul Cord Blood Bank] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070501082210/http://www.seoulcord.co.kr/bin/main.asp |date=1 May 2007 }} (SCB) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/1477865/Umbilical-cord-cells-allow-paralysed-woman-to-walk.html Umbilical cord cells 'allow paralysed woman to walk'] By Roger Highfield, Science Editor. Last Updated: 1:28AM GMT 30 November 2004</ref><ref>{{cite journal|pmid=16172374 | doi=10.1073/pnas.0507063102 | volume=102 | issue=39 | title=Human neural stem cells differentiate and promote locomotor recovery in spinal cord-injured mice | pmc=1216836 |date=September 2005 |vauthors=Cummings BJ, Uchida N, Tamaki SJ, etal | journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. | pages=14069–74}}</ref>

Stem-cell therapy for treatment of myocardial infarction usually makes use of autologous bone marrow stem cells, but other types of adult stem cells may be used, such as adipose-derived stem cells.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Paul A. |author2=Srivastava S. |author3=Chen G. |author4=Shum-Tim D. |author5=Prakash S. | year = 2011| title = Functional Assessment of Adipose Stem Cells for Xenotransplantation Using Myocardial Infarction Immunocompetent Models: Comparison with Bone Marrow Stem Cells | url = | journal = [[Cell Biochemistry and Biophysics]] | volume = 67| issue = 2| pages = 263–73| doi = 10.1007/s12013-011-9323-0 |pmid=22205499 }}</ref>
Possible mechanisms of recovery include:<ref name=NIH/> *Generation of heart muscle cells *Stimulating growth of new blood vessels to repopulate damaged heart tissue *Secretion of [[growth factors]]
====Criticisms====
In 2013, studies of autologous bone marrow stem cells on ventricular function were found to contain "hundreds" of discrepancies.<ref name="Dusseldorf Stem Cell Mystery">{{cite journal|last=Francis|first=Darrel P|title=Autologous bone marrow-derived stem cell therapy in heart disease: Discrepancies and contradictions|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167527313008012|journal=Int J Cardiol|accessdate=6 July 2013|doi=10.1016/j.ijcard.2013.04.152|pmid=23830344|volume=168|issue=4|date=Oct 2013|pages=3381–403}}</ref> Critics report that of 48 reports there seemed to be just five underlying trials, and that in many cases whether they were randomized or merely observational accepter-versus-rejecter, was contradictory between reports of the same trial. One pair of reports of identical baseline characteristics and final results, was presented in two publications as, respectively, a 578 patient randomized trial and as a 391 subject observational study. Other reports required (impossible) negative standard deviations in subsets of people, or contained fractional subjects, negative NYHA classes. Overall there were many more people published as having receiving stem cells in trials, than the number of stem cells processed in the hospital's laboratory during that time. A university investigation, closed in 2012 without reporting, was reopened in July 2013.<ref name="Strauer SZ">{{cite news|last=Berndt|first=Christina|title=A minefield of contradictions|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/wissen/vorwuerfe-gegen-stammzellforscher-ein-minenfeld-von-widerspruechen-1.1713007|publisher=Suddeutsche Zeitung|accessdate=6 July 2013|newspaper=Sueddeutsche.de|date=2013-07-04}}</ref>
